title.narrative: N/A
N/A
Programa de Apoyo para un Sistema de Educación Funcional
Support for a Seamless Education System Program

description.narrative: Apoyar la creación de un sistema educativo SEAMLESS, como propuesto por el Gobierno de Trinidad y Tobago, en el cual los niños pueden pasar de la etapa de Cuidado y Educación Temprana Infantil (ECCE) hasta la de educación terciaria de una manera articulada. Con este fin, este proyecto apoyará la mejora del acceso y calidad del ECCE, la articulación de los sub-sectores de educación y el fortalecimiento institucional del MOE para gestionar mejor el sector.

To support the creation of a seamless education system from early childhood to tertiary education as envisioned by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago to allow its citizens to progress smoothly from one level of the education system to the next. To this end, this project will improve the access and quality of Early Childhood Care and Education (ECCE), support the articulation of ECCE and primary education, and the strengthen the institutional capacity of the Ministry of Education to improve management of the education sector.

activity-description.narrative: IN PROGRESS The Arima ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for seventy-five (75) pupils. The size of the target population in the Arima area was one hundred and twenty eight (128) children. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI) who previously had access to only Private ECCE providers.

IN PROGRESS The Bamboo ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. The size of the target population in the area was one hundred and two (102) children. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI). This additional centre will increase the access to the population which had access to mainly Private ECCE providers.

IN PROGRESS The Bamboo ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. The size of the target population in the area was three hundred and sixteen (316) children. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI). This additional centre will increase the access to the population which had access to only Private ECCE providers.

IN PROGRESS The Barataria ECCE centre, which is assisted by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. The size of the target population in the Barataria area was two hundred and thirty (230) children. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI) who previously had access to only Private ECCE providers.

IN PROGRESS The Brothers ECCE centre will replace an existing ECCE centre housed in a Community Centre. It has a capacity for fifty (50) pupils to accommodate the target population of thirty four (34) children while increasing access to early childhood care education in neighbouring communities.

IN PROGRESS The Corinth ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. This centre was constructed to provide early childhood care education to a new Housing Development with a target population of fifty (50) children.

IN PROGRESS The Cunupia ECCE centre, which is assisted by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. The size of the target population in the Barataria area was two hundred (200) children. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI) who previously had access to only Private ECCE providers.

IN PROGRESS The Enterprise ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for seventy-five (75) pupils. The size of the target population in the area was eighty six (86) children. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI). While there is one additional publicly operated centre, the majority of the providers in the area are privately operated.

IN PROGRESS The Jacob's Hill ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. While there are 2 government/government assisted in the area, there was need for an additional centre. This centre was constructed to provide early childhood care education to a new Housing Development with a target population of one hundred and forty (140) children.

The Arouca, Pine Haven SDA ECCE centre, which is assisted by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. The size of the target population in the Arouca area was three hundred and eighty seven (387) children. It will address the early childhood care education needs with specific provision for children with special needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI) who previously had access to only Private ECCE providers.

The Madras ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI) who previously had access to mainly Private ECCE providers.

The Mount Hope ECCE centre, which is owned and operated by the Government of Trinidad and Tobago, was built with a capacity for fifty (50) pupils. It will address the early childhood care education needs of this population with a relatively low Basic Needs Index (BNI) who previously had access to mainly Private ECCE providers.
